newsitem.title: USA: Consumers pay last respects to Versace.
newsitem.headline: Consumers pay last respects to Versace.

text.p: Throngs of curious consumers flocked to stores across the United States on Friday seeking the creations of murdered Italian fashion designer Gianni Versace.
While Versace was laid to rest in a quiet graveyard in northern Italy, shoppers crowded into stores to buy the designer's creations.

"The day after (the murder) we started getting phone calls, and since then our Versace clothes have been flying off the racks," said Carol Selig, owner of the upscale Encore consignment store on Manhattan's Madison Avenue.

She said customers were coming in droves seeking a classic Versace piece. One woman paid $600 for a signatured dress and coat set cut from a colourful, Roman sculpture-inspired print; another paid $200 for a neon-green, super-tight dress.

Versace, 50, was shot to death on Tuesday outside his Miami Beach mansion by a lone gunman as he returned home from buying magazines. Police have mounted a massive manhunt for 27-year-old Andrew Cunanan, a homosexual prostitute and alleged "spree killer" whom they described as their only suspect.

At the 22 Bloomingdale's stores across the country, sales of Versace's secondary, moderately priced Versus line of clothing -- overseen by Versace's sister Donatella -- were up 20 percent, said a spokeswoman for the retail chain.

The retailer created a stark commemorative Versace window display at its flagship Lexington Avenue store, where, along with the Los Angeles branches, demand for the designer's items has been strongest.

A spokeswoman for the Neiman Marcus department store chain reported strong sales of relatively affordable Versace items like $95 ties, $350 five-piece china settings and Versace jeans, priced between $155 and $370.
In the Gianni Versace Boutique on Madison Avenue, sales of the very expensive couture pieces were no brisker than usual, but the store was unusually crowded.
